Award.AwardTitle: A Kilopixel, 2-Color, TES-Based Bolometer Camera for the IRAM 30 m Telescope
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mm/sub-mm spectral region is one of the last in the electromagnetic spectrum to benefit from fundamental developments in technology that lead to many-pixel, efficient detection of radiation. Transition Edge Sensors (TES) are small bolometers operating near the superconducting temperature boundary that can be constructed in array formats to efficiently detect sub-mm and mm-wave emission over an extended image. One of the primary scientific applications of these arrays is the detection of very young and obscured galaxies at high redshift that emit most of their light in the infrared and sub-mm spectral regions and provide direct information on early-epoch star formation and the formation and evolution of central black holes.

To attack these scientific problems, Dr. Johannes Staguhn of Johns Hopkins intends to build on the success of a previous NSF-supported TES-based mm-wave instrument called GIZMO with a larger format, lower-noise, two-band camera dubbed GIZMO-2. When used with the largest mm-wave telescope in the world - the 30-m IRAM telescope - the 1280-pixel array for the 1.2 mm wavelength will take advantage of nearly the entire usable field of view (5 x 4 arcminutes) with pixels somewhat smaller than the diffraction limit of ~9 arcseconds, and be capable of more efficiently mapping the sky at mm-wavelengths than any other camera available today. At the same time, measurements made with the 2 mm array will provide 2-color information that can be used to obtain crude source redshifts.

Cost-sharing for the development of GIZMO-2 is occurring through the participation of several agencies. NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center is providing the TES arrays, while the National Institute of Standards and Technology is supplying the state-of-the-art Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID) multiplexed readouts. NSF is responsible for the cryogenic apparatus, optics, integration, etc, using funding provided by the Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this proposal was  to build an astronomical  camera using large, superconducting detectors at two different wavelengths in order to obtain large scale, atmospheric background limited, high resolution bolometric astronomical observations of high redshift galaxies with unprecedented speed and efficiency. This project combined funding from the NSF with a significant contribution in form of the detector arrays from the  NASA/ Goddard Space Flight Cente Figure 1)r. The readout chips for the array, which also use superconductor based technologies, came from the National Institute of Standards in Boulder. GISMO-2 can take full advantage of the field of view provided by the optics of the IRAM 30m telescope, for which it was designed. The main gain in scientific capabilaty is enabled by these latest generation of these superconducting detectors and readout electronics.  GISMO-2’s detector noise is one order of magnitude below the background photon noise level and therefore provides for an exceptional  stability of the instrument. GISMO-2 enables confusion noise limited, simultaneous two color observations of an unexplored population of dusty high–redshift Luminous Infrared Galaxies (LIRGs) and the high redshift equivalent of sub-mm Galaxies (SMGs), and quasars in the epoch of early star formation in the universe at unprecedented speeds and with an observing efficiency that exceeds that of  all other existing millimeter bolometer cameras. In 4 hours of integration on the blank sky, the camera will detect 5 sources serendipitously on average, of which one will be at a redshift greater than 6, with a more than 50% likelihood that it will be simultaneously be detected at 2 mm, which will provide its photometric redshift. Furthermore, source stacking techniques will be used to trace high redshift galaxies with star formation rates typical for an average galaxy in the universe, down to galaxies with star formation rates comparable to our own. With the decision of IRAM to use an European bolometer camera, we have  entered into negotiations to move the instrument to either the JCMT on Mauna Kea, Hawaii, or the LMT in Mexico.

The surveys that will be conducted with the instrument will directly complement objectives addressed by the Herschel Space Observatory, ALMA, and the James Webb Space Telescope, as well as science generated by SCUBA-2. The instrument technology is based on a large format, close-packed, high-sensitivity bolometer array architecture suitable for use between 50 and 3,000 μm, which will find its first ground-based kilopixel array application in this instrument. These arrays will enable many future ground-based, suborbital, and space based instruments.

A close collaboration between the Johns Hopkins University, NASA/GSFC with the active involvement of students enables knowledge transfer and allows students to be involved in cutting edge technology developments at GSFC. The participation of students in the GSFC infrared instrumentation group, which has extensive experience in the field of superconducting detector technologies, is vital in educating the next generation of instrument scientists at JHU and other universities. The instrument and the detector technologies used in GISMO-2 combine key technologies provided by private industry (such as precision silicon optics) and technologies from other Federal Agencies (the SQUID multiplexers are provided by NIST/Boulder). A multiplexing system of the type we use in GISMO-2 will be a key technology for bringing arrays of such detectors to practical applications. Those include Terahertz imaging, which is e.g. a promising  technology  for passenger screening  at airports.
